G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: The Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this dispute involves the use, condition, or occupancy of residential property and arises under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 93A.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to damages as a result of Defendant’s failure to comply with Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 93A claims for unfair and deceptive practices, which may result from a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment (see *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 487 Mass. 543 (2022)).

*Johnson v. Rabelais*, 201 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: A landlord’s failure to address systemic issues that render a rental property unsafe or unsuitable constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14.

*Dartmouth v. Goodman*, 78 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: A landlord’s failure to address systemic issues that render a rental property unsafe or unsuitable constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Dartmouth v. Goodman*, 78 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns a criminal motion to suppress evidence arising from a vehicle stop and warrantless search after a shooting. It analyzes reasonable suspicion, probable cause, the automobile exception, and timing of a warrantless search; it does not involve landlord‑tenant law, habitability, or G.L. c. 186, § 14. Because the case never addresses a landlord’s duty to remedy unsafe rental conditions or statutory violations under c. 186, it cannot support the stated proposition.
*Dartmouth v. Goodman*, 78 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: The opinion discusses only criminal procedure issues surrounding a vehicle stop and search; there is no mention of G.L. c. 186, § 14 or landlord‑tenant obligations anywhere in the provided text.

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 487 Mass. 543 (202.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to damages as a result of Defendant’s failure to comply with Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 93A claims for unfair and deceptive practices, which may result from a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment (see *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 487 Mass. 543 (2022)).
